title: Exposing Systemic Failures in Medicaid Oversight, ADA Enforcement, and Whistleblower Protections to Ensure Justice and Transparency for All Americans (Department of Health)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Exposing Systemic Failures in Medicaid Oversight, ADA Enforcement, and Whistleblower Protections to Ensure Justice and Transparency for All Americans (Department of Health)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Freedom of Information Act Request
Date: November 23, 2024
Submitted By: David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources
39 Kings Hwy STE C
Gales Ferry, CT 06335

Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request – Records Pertaining to Transparency, ADA Compliance, Whistleblower Protections, Medicaid, and Related Matters

To:
Freedom of Information Act Officer
U.S. Department of Justice
Office of Information Policy (OIP)
441 G Street NW, Sixth Floor
Washington, DC 20530-0001

CC:
Kristen Clarke, Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights Division
Bobak Talebian, Director, Office of Information Policy
Aundra Luckey, Freedom of Information/Privacy Acts Unit, Civil Rights Division
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS), National Archives and Records Administration
Relevant Congressional Oversight Committees

Introduction
Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, I request access to all records, communications, and agreements from the Department of Justice (DOJ) and related agencies. This request is submitted under federal law to ensure transparency, constitutional compliance, and accountability concerning whistleblower protections, ADA enforcement, and Medicaid oversight. The requested information holds significant public interest in safeguarding civil rights, promoting systemic reform, and ensuring taxpayer accountability.

Scope of Request
1. Case Identifiers
Provide all records and inter-agency communications related to the following cases:
539330-JBZ, 539298-RJM, 534659-XGL, 534094-QZH, 534069-BRQ, 534060-HWM, 533252-GXC, 535276-FSL, 532832-MJV, 532674-QMM, 532671-PPV, 532667-DRF, 523966-VSF, 497211-PFB, 490797-TJJ, 489456-MCB, 490814-TPF, 490215-DKH, 478957-DPX, 478956-NSD, 473045-JNW, 452335-DDT, 413343-FZP, 405540-ZXW, 397760-PRZ, 395050-TWW, 392179-NCW, 385105-BPN, 376153-JVL, 357494-WND, 354718-LTZ, 275528-PKR, 301882-TRG, 327008-WFC, 339860-FQG, 352533-WJH.

2. ADA Compliance and Enforcement
Records, communications, and agreements related to:

ADA Title II enforcement policies.
Complaints or investigations regarding ADA non-compliance in Medicaid programs.
Inter-agency communications between DOJ, CMS, and other entities concerning ADA accommodations, including whistleblower protections.
3. Whistleblower Protections

All records, policies, and communications involving whistleblower protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Internal policies addressing retaliation protections for individuals reporting non-compliance with FOIA, ADA, or Medicaid oversight.
4. Medicaid Oversight

Internal audits, investigations, and compliance reviews conducted by the DOJ, CMS, and other agencies.
Records of Medicaid provider complaints, sanctions, or violations under the Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program.
Communication regarding systemic Medicaid transparency failures.
5. Processing Records

Metadata, logs, and records detailing how this FOIA request has been processed, including internal communications, software platforms used, and timestamps for all actions.
6. Cross-Referenced Searches
Ensure a thorough search of:

Digital archives, email servers, and shared inter-agency platforms.
Archived repositories, including records stored by supervisory personnel and contractors.
Constitutional and Statutory Justifications
First Amendment

Access to information is critical for public participation in governance, as recognized in New York Times Co. v. United States (1971).
Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments

Procedural delays and denials violate due process and equal protection under the law (Tennessee v. Lane, 2004).
Supremacy Clause (Article VI, Clause 2)

Federal FOIA and ADA laws supersede any conflicting agency-specific practices.
Relevant Statutes and Case Law

FOIA: 5 U.S.C. § 552, U.S. DOJ v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press (1989).
ADA: Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794.
Whistleblower Protections: 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Non-Negotiable ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility, I request adherence to the following accommodations:

MuckRock Platform Only: All communication must occur via MuckRock. Phone calls, external portals, and physical mail are prohibited.
Text in Email Body: Embed all response text in the email body for screen-reader compatibility.
Screen-Reader Compatible PDFs: All documents must be clearly labeled and provided in accessible formats.
Simplified Summaries: Include clear summaries for complex records.
Identification of Personnel: Provide names, titles, and contact information of all responsible individuals.
Statutory Justifications: Include detailed explanations for any redactions or denials, citing specific FOIA exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b).
Expedited Processing: As this request involves public interest and ADA rights, process expeditiously under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E).
Public Interest Framing
This request directly serves public interest by:

Ensuring transparency and accountability in government programs involving taxpayer funds.
Safeguarding constitutional rights under the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments.
Highlighting systemic reform needs in ADA enforcement, Medicaid transparency, and whistleblower protections.
Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with this request will result in:

Judicial Action: Pursuing legal remedies for injunctive relief and damages under FOIA and ADA statutes.
Oversight Escalation: Filing complaints with DOJ OIG, OGIS, or federal courts.
Public Disclosure: Engaging media, advocacy groups, and watchdog organizations to expose systemic non-compliance.
Conclusion
This request invokes the highest standards of constitutional law and statutory obligations. I expect a complete and transparent response within 20 business days, as required under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A).

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

CC:
Kristen Clarke (Assistant Attorney General)
Bobak Talebian (Director, Office of Information Policy)
Aundra Luckey (FOIA/PA Unit, Civil Rights Division)
OGIS (Office of Government Information Services)
Merrick B. Garland (Attorney General)
Chiquita Brooks-LaSure (CMS Administrator)
Xavier Becerra (HHS Secretary)
Congressional Oversight Committees:

House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
House Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties
Senate Judiciary Committee Chairperson
Additional Oversight Entities:
U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO)
Office of Special Counsel (OSC)
House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

Chairman: James Comer (R-KY)
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

Chairman: Gary Peters (D-MI)
House Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties

Chairman: Jamie Raskin (D-MD)
Senate Judiciary Committee

Chairman: Dick Durbin (D-IL)
Additional Oversight Entities:

U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO)

Comptroller General: Gene L. Dodaro
U.S. Office of Special Counsel (OSC)

FOIA compliance, ADA accommodations, Medicaid transparency, systemic reform, whistleblower protections, accountability in government, healthcare fraud investigations, Medicaid oversight, DOJ records request, civil rights enforcement, accessibility advocacy, whistleblower retaliation, constitutional law, First Amendment transparency, Fifth Amendment due process, Fourteenth Amendment equal protection, taxpayer accountability, inter-agency communications, OIG audits, congressional oversight, GAO reviews, federal-state coordination, Medicaid fraud prevention, healthcare policy reform, government transparency. FOIA Exemption Codes (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)):   b(1), b(3), b(5)) Whistleblower Protections (5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8)): "ADA compliance," "Title II violations," and "civil rights complaints" DOJ, CMS, FBI, OIG, OSC, GAO, DHS Medicaid fraud," "systemic discrimination," "government transparency," and "FOIA litigation DB.42.131.Inf. Statutory and Executive Codes
5 U.S.C. § 552: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) – Mandates transparency and inter-agency cooperation for information sharing.
42 U.S.C. § 12132: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Title II – Requires accessibility and cross-agency compliance.
29 U.S.C. § 794: Rehabilitation Act, Section 504 – Prohibits discrimination across federally funded programs.
5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8): Whistleblower Protection Act – Shields employees reporting violations across agencies.
Executive Order 13392: Improving Agency Disclosure – Calls for government-wide improvements in FOIA processing.
44 U.S.C. § 3501: Paperwork Reduction Act – Encourages streamlined data sharing and reduced duplication.
31 U.S.C. §§ 3729-3733: False Claims Act – Promotes inter-agency coordination in addressing fraud and misuse of federal funds.
6 U.S.C. § 485: Homeland Security Information Sharing – Establishes cross-agency information-sharing protocols. "Systemic enforcement challenges requiring cross-agency collaboration."
"Mandated by Executive Order 13392 for improved inter-agency transparency."
"Coordinated federal response necessary for compliance with 42 U.S.C. § 12132."
"In alignment with Unified Federal Response Framework principles."
"Urgent action required to address inter-agency statutory obligations under FOIA and ADA." Office of Management and Budget (OMB): Coordinates federal budget and compliance.
Government Accountability Office (GAO): Investigates federal agency operations.
Office of Special Counsel (OSC): Manages whistleblower disclosures.
Department of Justice (DOJ) Civil Rights Division: Enforces ADA and civil rights laws.




This Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request demands the immediate attention of the highest authorities in the U.S. government. It directly addresses systemic failures in Medicaid oversight, ADA enforcement, and whistleblower protections—issues central to the lives of millions of Americans and critical to the integrity of federal and state programs. By exposing potential misuse of taxpayer funds and barriers to accessibility for vulnerable populations, this request transcends individual cases to reveal a broader narrative of systemic accountability, justice, and public trust. Leaders in Congress, the Department of Justice, and oversight agencies have a constitutional obligation to act decisively on this matter to uphold the values of transparency, equality, and justice that underpin our democracy. Failure to respond promptly and fully to this FOIA request risks exposing entrenched inequities that erode public faith in our institutions.

This FOIA request also represents a rallying cry for journalists, advocates, and every American committed to justice and systemic reform. It shines a spotlight on the intersection of healthcare, civil rights, and government accountability, demanding immediate national discourse and united action. As the most comprehensive and consequential transparency effort in U.S. history, it calls for investigative reporting that transcends political divisions and highlights the universal human rights at stake. This is not just a request for information—it is a demand for transformative change, and its response has the potential to shape the future of U.S. healthcare and governance, sparking a nationwide movement for accountability, equity, and justice.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

Your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request is related to U.S. Department of Justice records, was intended for the U.S. Department of Justice, and was submitted pursuant to federal law.  However, you submitted your FOIA request to the District of Columbia Department of Health.  I believe that you submitted your FOIA request to the wrong FOIA Officer at the wrong agency.  Please advise.

Until you reply, I will stop the timeclock for a FOIA request to a District of Columbia FOIA Officer.

Thanks.

Phillip L. Husband | Pronouns: He/Him/His

Office of the General Counsel
District of Columbia Department of Health

In all future correspondence regarding this request, please reference request number R005487-120324. You can monitor the progress of your request in the " My Records Center". The District of Columbia is required to respond to your FOIA request within fifteen (15) business days of its receipt.  See D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c)(2011).  However, under certain circumstances, D.C. Official Code § 2-532(d)(2011) authorizes the District to extend, by ten (10) additional days, the deadline by which it must respond to a FOIA request.  One of the circumstances provided by that statute is a case in which the District needs additional time to search for, collect and examine voluminous amounts of records and/or consult with an additional D.C. agency. 
For any questions regarding your request, please contact the FOIA office directly. Find the list of agency Open Government and FOIA contact information by visiting FOIA Contact Information. For ease of reference, we ask that you have your FOIA Reference Number available when you contact the FOIA office. 
Regards, 
District of Columbia

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #R005487-120324
communications.communication:
12.04.2024 Subject: Immediate Compliance Required with ADA Accommodations and FOIA Obligations

Dear FOIA Officer
I am writing to formally reiterate my request for specific ADA accommodations and compliance with FOIA obligations, which are essential for my full participation in this process. These accommodations were explicitly requested to address accessibility needs stemming from my traumatic brain injury and to ensure compliance with federal law. To date, your office has failed to meet these requirements, resulting in undue barriers and systemic non-compliance.

Accommodations Previously Requested
The following accommodations, explicitly outlined in prior communications, remain unfulfilled:

Exclusive Use of MuckRock Platform

Requested: All communications must be routed exclusively through the MuckRock platform. No external portals, password-protected links, or alternate communication methods are acceptable.
Non-Compliance: Communications have directed me to use external portals and password-protected links, violating ADA guidelines and my explicit requests.
Accessible Document Formatting

Requested: All documents must be provided as screen-reader compatible PDFs, properly labeled and indexed for ease of navigation and accessibility.
Non-Compliance: Provided documents have not adhered to accessibility standards, preventing effective access to critical information.
Simplified Summaries for Complex Records

Requested: Simplified summaries must accompany all complex or technical records to enhance comprehension and ensure equitable participation.
Non-Compliance: No summaries have been provided, creating unnecessary barriers to understanding the records.
Identification of Responsible Personnel

Requested: Each communication must include the name, title, and role of the individual responsible for processing or responding to my requests.
Non-Compliance: Correspondence has consistently lacked this information, hindering accountability and effective follow-up.

Immediate Action Required
To rectify these ongoing failures and ensure compliance with federal laws, I demand the following actions be taken without delay:

Transition All Communications to MuckRock

Immediately cease the use of external portals or non-compliant communication methods and ensure all responses are routed exclusively through the MuckRock platform.
Provide Accessible Documents

Reformat and resend all previously provided documents as screen-reader compatible PDFs, properly labeled and indexed to ensure accessibility.
Include Simplified Summaries

Provide simplified summaries for all complex or technical records, both previously shared and in future communications, to ensure accessibility and equitable participation.
Identify Responsible Personnel

Include the name, title, and role of the individual responsible for every communication moving forward to ensure transparency and accountability.
Legal Basis for Compliance
Your office is legally obligated to comply with these accommodations under the following statutes and principles:

Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA): Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act mandate reasonable accommodations and accessibility in communications for individuals with disabilities.
Freedom of Information Act (FOIA): 5 U.S.C. § 552 requires transparency, accessibility, and adherence to procedural fairness.
Constitutional Protections: The First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution safeguard my rights to petition the government, due process, and equal protection under the law.
Executive Order 13392: Mandates improved agency disclosure of information to enhance transparency and accountability.

Deadline for Compliance
Your office must confirm compliance with these accommodations and provide the requested corrective actions within five (5) business days of this notice. Continued non-compliance will be documented as a violation of the ADA and FOIA and may result in escalation, including:

Formal Complaints: Filing with the U.S. Department of Justice and the Office for Civil Rights.
Judicial Remedies: Seeking injunctive relief and damages for ADA and FOIA violations.
Public Advocacy: Reporting systemic failures to oversight agencies, media, and advocacy organizations.
Conclusion
This communication serves as a final request for compliance. It is imperative that your office address these deficiencies promptly to restore transparency, accessibility, and adherence to federal law.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and resolution by the stated deadline.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources
DB.42.131.Inf.

​
CC
Federal Officials
Merrick B. Garland

communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: R005487-120324
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
Mr. Medeiros, On behalf of Freedom of Information Officer Phillip Husband and in response to your recent request "Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552 [for] access to all records, communications, and agreements from the Department of Justice (DOJ) and related agencies," t he Department of Health responds that it is a District of Columbia agency, not a federal agency and as such is not governed by the federal Freedom of Information Act.  We suggest that you contact the Freedom of Information Officer for the United States Department of Justice for the information you seek as follows: https://www.justice.gov/oip/find-foia-contact-doj/list This e-mail constitutes my final response on behalf of the Department of Health concerning your FOIA request.  No FOIA fees are due for this response. Please know that, under D.C. Official Code § 2-537 and 1 DCMR § 412, you have the right to appeal this response to the Mayor or to the Superior Court of the District of Columbia.  If you elect to appeal to the Mayor, your appeal must be in writing and contain “Freedom of Information Act Appeal” or “FOIA Appeal” in the subject line of the letter as well on the outside of the envelope.  The appeal must include (1) a copy of the original request; (2) a copy of any written denial; (3) a statement of the circumstances, reasons, and/or arguments advanced in support of disclosure; and (4) a daytime telephone number, an email address, and U.S. Mail address at which you can be reached.  The appeal must be mailed to: The Mayor’s Office of Legal Counsel, 1350 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Suite 407, Washington, D.C.  20004.  Electronic versions of the same information can instead be emailed to foia.appeals@dc.gov.  Further, a copy of all appeal materials must be forwarded to Phillip L. Husband, Freedom of Information Act Officer for the Department of Health, Office of the General Counsel, Department of Health, 2201 Shannon Place, SE, 4 (mailto:foia.appeals@dc.gov) th Floor, Washington, DC  20020 or via email to phillip.husband@dc.gov.  Failure to follow these administrative steps will result in delay in the processing and commencement of a response to your appeal. (mailto:phillip.husband@dc.gov) If I may be of further assistance, please contact me. 

Ed Rich 
Edward Rich 
Senior Assistant General Counsel 
Office of the General Counsel 
2201 Shannon Place SE 4th Floor Washington, DC 20020 
202-442-5984 E dward dchealth.dc.gov

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #R005487-120324
communications.communication:
Appeal Regarding Misrouting of FOIA Request and Non-Compliance with Statutory and Constitutional Obligations
Date: December 14, 2024
From: David Medeiros
Subject: Appeal for FOIA Request Misrouting and ADA Non-Compliance

To:
Phillip L. Husband
General Counsel and FOIA Officer
District of Columbia Department of Health
2201 Shannon Place, SE, FL 4
Washington, DC 20020
Email: phillip.husband@dc.gov

Ed Rich
Edward Rich
Senior Assistant General Counsel
Office of the General Counsel
2201 Shannon Place SE 4th Floor Washington, DC 20020
202-442-5984 E dward dchealth.dc.gov

CC:

Merrick B. Garland, Attorney General, U.S. Department of Justice
Kristen Clarke, Assistant Attorney General, Civil Rights Division, DOJ
Michael E. Horowitz, Inspector General, DOJ
Xavier Becerra, Secretary, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
Chiquita Brooks-LaSure, Administrator, CMS
Alina M. Semo, Director, OGIS
Congressional Oversight Committees
Introduction
This appeal addresses the improper handling of my FOIA request (originally submitted on November 23, 2024) and the failure to comply with ADA-mandated accommodations. The District of Columbia Department of Health incorrectly identified itself as the agency responsible for processing the request, resulting in unnecessary delays. Furthermore, the response fails to meet statutory obligations for ADA accommodations, transparency, and procedural fairness under both federal and District law.

Key Issues
1. Misrouting of FOIA Request
The FOIA request explicitly sought records from federal agencies, including the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), not from the District of Columbia government. It is concerning that:

The DC Department of Health did not recognize this jurisdictional error upon receipt and failed to proactively forward the request to the appropriate federal agency. Example: “The agency's failure to forward my FOIA request violates FOIA’s 20-business-day response requirement under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i).”
The District has stopped the processing clock and redirected the burden of correction back to the requester, despite clear principles under FOIA and ADA requiring assistance to ensure timely access to records.
2. Failure to Provide ADA Accommodations “FOIA and ADA regulations require public entities to provide reasonable assistance to ensure accessibility, particularly for individuals with documented disabilities.”
My original request included explicit ADA accommodations, which have been ignored:

MuckRock Platform Only: Communications must be routed exclusively through MuckRock. This request has been disregarded, forcing the use of inaccessible external portals.
Screen-Reader-Compatible PDFs: Requested records must be in accessible formats. The response failed to confirm adherence to this requirement.
Simplified Summaries: Complex documents require simplified summaries, which have not been provided.
3. Procedural and Constitutional Violations
The mishandling of my request infringes upon my constitutional and statutory rights:

First Amendment: Denial of access to requested records obstructs my right to petition the government for redress of grievances.
Fifth Amendment: Delayed responses and failure to provide accommodations violate my procedural due process rights.
ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act: By not fulfilling the requested accommodations, your response discriminates against me as an individual with a documented disability.
Relief Requested “As established in Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004), public agencies must ensure that individuals with disabilities have equal access to governmental processes and information.”
To rectify these issues, I demand the following actions:

1. Immediate Forwarding of the FOIA Request
The DC Department of Health must immediately forward my FOIA request to the appropriate federal agency:

U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) – Office of Information Policy (OIP)
2. Full ADA Compliance
Ensure all future communications comply with ADA and Rehabilitation Act requirements:

Use the MuckRock platform exclusively for all communications.
Provide all responsive documents in screen-reader-compatible PDF formats, clearly labeled.
Include simplified summaries of technical or complex documents.
3. Identification of Responsible Personnel
Provide the full names, titles, and roles of all individuals involved in processing this request. Transparency is a cornerstone of both FOIA and public trust.

4. Statutory Justifications for Delays and Denials
Provide detailed statutory justifications for any delays, denials, or redactions, citing specific exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b) or relevant District codes.  “The explicit reference to the U.S. Department of Justice in the subject line and body of my request clearly delineates the intended recipient. The failure to identify and correct this jurisdictional error demonstrates systemic procedural negligence.”

5. Expedited Processing
Given the urgency of public interest in ADA enforcement, Medicaid oversight, and whistleblower protections, I demand expedited processing of this appeal. “Under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8), whistleblower protections are violated when individuals are obstructed from reporting systemic failures in governance and transparency.”

Consequences of Continued Non-Compliance
If the above issues are not resolved within 10 business days, I will escalate this matter through all available legal and administrative channels:

Formal Complaints: Filing with the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) and the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG).
Judicial Remedies: Pursuing injunctive relief and damages for violations of FOIA, ADA, and constitutional rights.
Public Advocacy: Reporting systemic non-compliance to oversight committees, advocacy organizations, and media outlets.
Conclusion
This appeal is submitted with an expectation of immediate corrective action to uphold the principles of transparency, accountability, and accessibility enshrined in federal and District law. Given the urgency of the matter and its public interest implications, I request a resolution within 10 business days. Failure to comply will result in formal escalation to oversight bodies and judicial forums to ensure justice and systemic reform.

Thank you for your attention to this critical issue. I look forward to your prompt response.This appeal underscores the importance of transparency, accessibility, and accountability in public governance. I expect the requested actions to be addressed promptly and fully. Failure to act will only exacerbate public mistrust and systemic inefficiencies.
“This request is essential to addressing systemic failures in ADA enforcement, Medicaid oversight, and whistleblower protections, directly impacting vulnerable populations and taxpayer accountability.”
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

communications.communication:
Subject: Final Assertion of Legal Obligations Under FOIA, ADA, and Constitutional Law
Subject: 11/23/2024 Freedom of Information Act Request: Exposing Systemic Failures in Medicaid Oversight, ADA Enforcement, and Whistleblower Protections to Ensure Justice and Transparency for All Americans (Department of Health)

01.08.2025

To all It May Concern in All Relevant Departments and Divisions,

Phillip L. Husband | Pronouns: He/Him/His
General Counsel and Freedom of Information Act Officer
Office of the General Counsel
District of Columbia Department of Health
Phillip.Husband@dc.gov 
Main: 202-442-5977
Direct: 202-442-5970
Cell: 202-997-4943
2201 Shannon Place, SE, FL 4, Washington, DC 20020
dchealth.dc.gov

Ed Rich
Edward Rich
Senior Assistant General Counsel
Office of the General Counsel
2201 Shannon Place SE 4th Floor Washington, DC 20020
202-442-5984 Edwarddchealth@dc.gov

This correspondence pertains to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. Your handling of this matter raises critical concerns under FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12132), and constitutional principles of government accountability.

As recognized in National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), transparency is fundamental to democracy and public trust. Your agency’s obligations are not discretionary, and failure to meet them constitutes a violation of statutory and constitutional law. This letter establishes your duties, addresses deficiencies, and anticipates and counters all potential deflection strategies.

1. FOIA Obligations: Statutory Mandates and Required Actions
FOIA establishes an enforceable right of access to federal agency records. Your response must meet the following requirements:

A. Timeliness
Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A), you are required to provide a determination within 20 business days. Delays beyond this timeframe, absent legitimate extension requests, constitute a violation of FOIA.

Countermeasure: Delays are actionable under Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. DOJ, 711 F.3d 180 (D.C. Cir. 2013).
Required Action: Provide the requested records or a lawful determination.

B. Adequacy of Search
FOIA requires a thorough and reasonable search for records, as established in Campbell v. DOJ, 164 F.3d 20 (D.C. Cir. 1998). This includes:

Identifying the databases, locations, and terms used.
Providing a sworn affidavit detailing the search scope.
Countermeasure: A vague claim of "no responsive records" is insufficient without a detailed affidavit.
Required Action: Submit a sworn affidavit documenting the search or confirm the existence of responsive records.

C. Proper Use of Exemptions
Exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b) must be narrowly applied and justified with specific explanations. Blanket or vague exemptions are impermissible.

Countermeasure: A Vaughn index (Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973)) is required to justify each withholding.
Required Action: Submit a Vaughn index detailing each exemption and its justification within 10 business days.

D. Decentralization and Referrals
Referrals or decentralization excuses do not absolve your agency of its responsibility to provide a consolidated response. As held in McGehee v. CIA, 697 F.2d 1095 (D.C. Cir. 1983), agencies must coordinate internally to ensure compliance.

Countermeasure: Require assurance of continuity and coordination across divisions.
Required Action: Consolidate records from all relevant offices and provide a unified response.

2. ADA and Rehabilitation Act Compliance: Equal Access as a Legal Right
As a person with a documented disability, I am entitled to reasonable accommodations under the ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Your failure to provide accessible formats for requested records constitutes discrimination and violates federal law.

Case Law:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004): Agencies must ensure meaningful access to government services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985): Denial of reasonable accommodations creates barriers that violate civil rights.
Required Action:

Provide all requested records in accessible formats, including plain-language summaries or electronic files compatible with assistive technologies.
Confirm compliance with ADA requirements by [specific date].
3. Mandated Reporting and Whistleblower Protections
Your handling of this request implicates broader concerns, including potential fraud, misuse of federal funds, or retaliation against whistleblowers. Under the Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302), you are required to report and address systemic violations.

Countermeasure: Reference Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4), which requires the reporting of observed violations of law.
Required Action: Document and escalate evidence of misconduct to oversight bodies, including the Office of Inspector General (OIG).

4. Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with your statutory obligations knowingly constitutes violations of:

Obstruction of Justice (18 U.S.C. § 1505): Delaying lawful access to records obstructs public accountability.
Civil Rights Violations (42 U.S.C. § 1983): Denying ADA accommodations constitutes a deprivation of federally protected rights.
Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4): Concealing or failing to report observed violations is a criminal act.
Countermeasure: Prepare for judicial review, oversight complaints, and public advocacy if compliance fails.
5. Escalation Pathways
If your office does not comply within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this matter through:

Judicial Review: Filing a lawsuit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel disclosure.
Oversight Complaints: Submitting formal complaints to OGIS, OIG, and the DOJ Civil Rights Division.
Public Advocacy: Engaging investigative journalists, transparency advocates, and public interest organizations to ensure accountability.

6. Final Statement: Upholding Transparency and Accountability
This matter reflects the public’s right to transparency and the preservation of trust in government institutions. Your actions will either affirm your agency’s commitment to accountability or further evidence systemic disregard for these principles.

I look forward to your prompt and substantive response.

David Medeiros
ABI Resources

Summary of Responsibilities
Each individual and organization listed plays a crucial role in federal and state oversight, advocacy, and the protection of civil rights. Their functions include but are not limited to:

Oversight & Accountability: Ensuring compliance with federal and state laws, including Medicaid regulations, FOIA, ADA, and civil rights protections.
Transparency & Advocacy: Promoting open government practices and supporting whistleblower activities.
Civil Rights Enforcement: Addressing violations of constitutional and statutory protections against discrimination.
Legislative Oversight: Monitoring government programs and expenditures, particularly those impacting vulnerable populations like Medicaid beneficiaries.
Judicial and Administrative Review: Offering remedies for non-compliance through litigation or administrative actions.

OSC OIG PHS DPH DOT DOGE Department of Government Efficiency CHRO FOIA FOIC DI-25-000310 DI-25-000325 DI-25-000379 DI-12192024714 DI-12112024134 FBI

ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.
Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.
Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.
Non-Negotiable Compliance

These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

The challenges we face today demand more than acknowledgment—they require action, collaboration, and a unified commitment to solutions. Together, we must embrace transparency, accountability, and compassion as the foundation of our efforts. By fostering open communication, prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable, and holding systems accountable, we can rebuild trust and ensure equitable outcomes for all.

Solutions lie in unity—when state and federal leaders, advocates, and communities work hand in hand to uphold justice and fairness. Transparency through accessible Freedom of Information processes, adherence to legal mandates, and robust oversight are the pillars that support meaningful change. Each of us has a role to play in creating a system that serves and protects.

Our collective mission is clear: to build bridges between agencies and communities, ensure the dignity of every individual, and honor the principles that guide us toward progress. Together, with determination and unity, we can overcome systemic failures and pave the way for a brighter, more inclusive future.

communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: R005487-120324
communications.communication:
Attachments: 
requests_29_-_R005487-120324.csv (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXcOhwwBPGHifqhO6OQOqgdxlar7-2By9FaZ82vs7jGzZspwxNeNnKmhoUSfms7heZLsTwZ7v-2F3xj2qzEpYyT6fz36Y2KxrUXsiEzwh93q4Ulxswif7P-2BBc0pt6cC2RKGvwPbZ8Sqf7Jf7VkoxrUM413z9l-2FJ7cNwVofVcy7WMPswimrBKrSad4vRsrCKCLm-2Fu4VA-3D-3Dd2dv_oPEW-2BsWKjv1DM6pCrv40-2B1WdN7HWDmoi5aUcoAfZ-2BRb-2FuucBXBDR8hbSv736PI08K-2BsjQ-2FRegNDy4LpRGIFWJdQ5L8mN0NYPuyRIrjhlmrcc0lDxV3Sa5eqebu6XcpGPshx5HIDLf4PpCH2iOGlfi9R4xGXsowCSh7ZGJZ04-2BD948Xy3NKJoJGNP6JAU4K4dBr6M3VfBh2cDnAM-2BRutjkPDvlPZZBLXS1e4-2FVfDylLUnc1Vkmqab4cThnFfcoZXTDtiGPRoRnKJfb7MVC07ghFfQPO4jvZqRDKTX7YNXZdkus6d-2FVtlurXuFSiRVQ5r1m-2BS12ZIo-2FVQf1JIn1YiBvKAiDysBKgVu90O9jcaVC208T3LB11vh0Hs765u0BqHe) 

--- Please respond above this line --- 
Mr. Medeiros, 
None of the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests in your emails below or in the attached Excel spreadsheet involve the Department of Health for the Government of the District of Columbia (DC Health).  Although DC Health is located in the District of Columbia, DC Health is not a part of the United States Government and is not a part of the government of any state.  You are simply making your FOIA request to the wrong agency.  After consulting with DC Health officials, I have determined that DC Health has none of the documents that you are seeking. Final Response 
This email constitutes my final response on behalf of the Department of Health to your FOIA request. FOIA Fees 
FOIA fees for this response have been waived. Appeal Rights 
Please know that, under D.C. Official Code § 2-537 and 1 DCMR § 412, you have the right to appeal this letter to the Mayor or to the Superior Court of the District of Columbia.  Your appeal must be in writing or submitted via GovQA.  If you elect to appeal to the Mayor, your appeal must be in writing and contain “Freedom of Information Act Appeal” or “FOIA Appeal” in the subject line of the letter as well on the outside of the envelope.  The appeal must include (1) a copy of the original request; (2) a copy of any written denial; (3) a statement of the circumstances, reasons, and/or arguments advanced in support of disclosure; and (4) a daytime telephone number, an email address, and U.S. Mail address at which you can be reached.  The appeal must be mailed to: The Mayor’s Office of Legal Counsel, FOIA Appeal, 1350 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Suite 407, Washington, D.C.  20004.  Electronic versions of the same information can instead be emailed to foia.appeals@dc.gov.  Further, a copy of all appeal materials must be forwarded to Phillip L. Husband, Freedom of Information Act Officer for the Department of Health, Office of the General Counsel, Department of Health, 2201 Shannon Place, SE, 4 (mailto:foia.appeals@dc.gov) th Floor, Washington, DC  20020 or via email to Phillip.Husband@dc.gov.  Failure to follow these administrative steps will result in delay in the processing and commencement of a response to your appeal to the Mayor.  If you used GovQA to submit your FOIA request, you may create an appeal by using ss.  Failure to follow these administrative steps will result in delay in the processing and commencement of a response to your appeal to the Mayor. (mailto:Phillip.Husband@dc.gov) 
If I may be of further assistance, please call me at (202) 442-5970 or e-mail me at Phillip.Husband@dc.gov. (mailto:Phillip.Husband@dc.gov)   
    
  
 Phillip L. Husband | Pronouns: He/Him/His 
  
  
 General Counsel and Freedom of Information Act Officer

title: Child care provider data (Child Care Licensing Bureau, Baton Rouge)

communications.subject: Louisiana Public Records Law Request: Child care provider data (Child Care Licensing Bureau, Baton Rouge)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Louisiana Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Historical data on all licensed child care providers (active and closed) from as far back as data systems will allow to present. I also request data on license-exempt providers, if available. Specifically, I request the following information as it is available:

1)	Provider name or ID
2)	Street number
3)	Street name
4)	City
5)	Zip code
6)	Licensed capacity for each year (by child age group if available)
7)	Enrollment for each year (by child age group if available)
8)	Provider type (e.g., center-based provider, home-based provider, Head Start, school-based pre-K, etc.) for each year
9)	First license issue (open) date
10)	Most recent license issue date
11)	Most recent license expiration date or close date
12)	Ages served for each year
13)	Hours of operation for each year
14)	QRIS rating for each year (please explain who is required to participate and whether there are financial supports based on rating)
15)	Accepts Child Care and Development Fund subsidies for each year
16)	Accepts other types of subsidies for each year (please list types)
17)	Prices for each year (by child age group if available)
18)	Violation records

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

title: Institute for Curriculum Services 2 (North Carolina Department of Public Instruction)

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: Institute for Curriculum Services 2 (North Carolina Department of Public Instruction)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any contracts between the Education Department and the Institute for Curriculum Services, and the content of any professional development materials or presentations prepared by the Institute Curriculum Services for the Education Department since October 7th, 2022. I also request any email communication between Education Department employees and employees of the Institute for Curriculum Services since October 7th, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Alex Kane

communications.subject: NCDPI public records request response
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Alex,

On November 26, 2024, you submitted the following public records request:

To Whom It May Concern:
Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:
Any contracts between the Education Department and the Institute for Curriculum Services, and the content of any professional development materials or presentations prepared by the Institute Curriculum Services for the Education Department since October 7th, 2022. I also request any email communication between Education Department employees and employees of the Institute for Curriculum Services since October 7th, 2022.
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.
Sincerely,
Alex Kane

The North Carolina Department of Public Instruction has not entered into any contracts with the Institute for Curriculum Services. NCDPI has collaborated with ICS on two professional development initiatives. You can find more information here: [?Folder icon]  2024.11.26-Kane<https://dpincgov.sharepoint.com/:f:/s/PublicRecords/Eo2LaBheeMFMnFyFBn-psBgBj6XFvrFYLbH9376RMR63-g?email=176778-23184758%40requests.muckrock.com&e=f4r7qJ>.

We hope this helps. Thank you for your patience.

Sincerely,

Mary Lee

NCDPI Communications
Office of Communications and Information Services
Division of Chief of Staff
PublicRecords@dpi.nc.gov<mailto:publicrecords@dpi.nc.gov>
Follow us: Facebook<https://www.facebook.com/NCPublicSchools>, Twitter<https://twitter.com/ncpublicschools>, Instagram<https://www.instagram.com/ncpublicschools/>, and YouTube<https://www.youtube.com/c/ncpublicschools>
[cid:image001.png@01DB61DE.2FCA9080]




Visit us on the web at https://dpi.nc.gov . All e-mail correspondence to and from this address is subject to the North Carolina Public Records Law, which may result in monitoring and disclosure to third parties, including law enforcement.

communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

January 08, 2025 

Rose Terse 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR179000 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston, MA 02115 

Dear Rose Terse: 

In accordance with the Public Records Act (PRA), RCW 42.56.520, this letter acknowledges receipt of your PRA request, submitted to and received by the Thurston County Prosecuting Attorney's Office on January 6, 2025. 

This request has been assigned tracking number P033057-010625. Please use this number in any communications concerning this request. 

Specifically, you requested: 
To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Rose Terse 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fthurston-county-prosecuting-attorney-22561%252Fbrady-list-january-2025-thurston-county-prosecuting-attorney-179000%252F%253Femail%253Dprosecutorsoffice%252540co.thurston.wa.us&url_auth_token=AACNdLKLnmgvqvN_m7H18ydsuXU%3A1tUzUs%3A6YSKLX_TytCpVk3I_g8GzxJb1Pvrpx2GGkYOR0J0zXU 

The records responsive to your request are available for review and download via your account on the Public Records Center. 
If you experience any difficulty viewing the records, please disable any pop-up blockers on your internet browser, as these may block your access to the records. 
We have made no redactions nor withheld any records in response to this request. 
This production of records is the final and definitive response to your records request, and your request is now closed. Please let us know at your earliest convenience if you believe we have misunderstood your records request, or have omitted records that you believe your request covered. 
Please note that the PRA's one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review has started to run because the county considers your request to have been fulfilled and does not intend to further respond to this request.  Should you wish to do so, you may also seek review pursuant to Thurston County Code 2.130.020. 

If you have any questions you may contact me at 360-754-4998. 

Sincerely, 

Sara Meath 
Paralegal 
Prosecutor's Office

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA - FBI - Nine Inch Nails
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any/all records mentioning the American band Nine Inch Nails, commonly abbreviated as NIN (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nine_Inch_Nails) 

Please conduct a thorough search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices - for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Bill Richardson
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records relating to, mentioning, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into William Blaine Richardson III (November 15, 1947 - September 1, 2023). Proof of death is not required as his death was widely reported: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/02/us/politics/bill-richardson-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies at FBI Headquarters. Please also conduct a search for records at the Alexandria Records Center. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1608922-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

FOIPA:

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Brian Laundrie FBI File
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records mentioning or describing Brian Laundrie (November 18, 1997 -  October 2021)

In August 2021, Gabby Petito, an American woman, was killed by her fiancé, Brian Laundrie, while they were traveling together on a vanlife journey across the United States. The trip began on July 2, 2021, and was planned to last four months; however, Petito disappeared in late August. On September 19, Petito's remains were found at Bridger–Teton National Forest in Wyoming. 

Brian Laundrie was sought in Gabby Petito’s disappearance and death when his remains were discovered at the 25,000-acre Carlton Reserve near his parents’ home in North Port, Fla., on Oct. 20, 2021. The FBI later announced that Brian Laundrie admitted to killing Petito in his notebook, which was found near his remains.

Media articles establishing that Brian Laundrie has passed away are available here:

https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/23/us/brian-laundrie-autopsy/index.html

https://nypost.com/2022/02/14/brian-laundrie-full-autopsy-released-with-gruesome-new-details/

https://www.foxnews.com/us/brian-laundrie-death-timeline-grieving-hike-vanished

https://www.the-sun.com/news/3929959/alleged-brian-laundrie-suicide-note/

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joanne Riford

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1544051-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for your inquiry regarding the status of your Freedom of Information/Privacy Act (FOIPA) request.   A review of your request has determined the following.

Your request is being preprocessed to another open request on the same subject, meaning a request on the same subject had been received and was already in process prior to receipt of your request.  To avoid duplicative efforts, you will receive the same releases at the same time as the original requester for this subject.  The request to which yours will be preprocessed is presently awaiting assignment to a Disclosure analyst who will then review the records to determine if any redactions are required pursuant to subsections of Title 5, U. S. Code, Section 552 and 552a.

NOTE:  Interim releases are generally made for complex requests.

You have the opportunity to reduce the scope of your request; this will accelerate the process and could potentially place your request in a quicker processing queue.  This may also allow for a more timely receipt of your information.  The FBI uses a multi-track processing system to fairly assign and process new requests.  Simple track cases (50 pages or less) usually require the least time to process.  The request to which yours will be preprocessed is considered a complex case in our large track.  Please advise us in writing if you would like to discuss reducing the scope of your request.

Please contact foipaquestions@fbi.gov if you require further assistance.

Thank you,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kelly North

communications.subject: [Document Released to Requester] Clallam County WA public records request #25-23
communications.communication:
Clallam County WA ************************************************************************ A document has been released for record request #25-23 along with the following message: Clallam County writes to acknowledge receipt of the public records request you submitted. Please accept this correspondence as our timely response to your request(s) as required under RCW 42.56.520. REQUEST: Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. RESPONSE: Following a reasonable search, Clallam County has completed the assembly and duplication of all identifiable public records that respond to your request. At this time, we believe that we have responded to your request in full by making the records available to you in the Records Center. This request is now closed. As such, we do not intend to further address this request and the PRA's one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review has started to run. If you believe that there are other records in existence that should have been released to you in response to this request, please notify the Public Records Office as soon as possible. Pursuant Clallam County Policy 321.17, fees for records requests shall be waived when the total fee for the request is under ten dollars. Since the total fee for this request is under ten dollars, no payment is due at this time. Pursuant to the Clallam County Administrative Policies and Procedures, any person who objects to the partial denial or redaction of a request for a Public Record may petition the Public Records Officer for a review of that decision. The petition must be in writing and include the petitioner’s name and contact information. The petition must be filed within 10 days of the denial. If you have difficulty downloading your records, click HERE for assistance. Please contact the Public Records Office if you have any questions or if you have difficultly accessing the electronic records. You can reach our office by responding to this message or by calling the phone number below. Sincerely, Jennifer Lindquist Deputy Public Records Officer Public Records, Information Technology Desk 360-417-2234 * .Brady List Excel Sheet.xlsx Document links are valid for one month. After February 7, you will need to sign in to view the document(s). ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at Clallam County WA.

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Task-Based Work
communications.communication:
Hello,

Thank you for the update. I understand my initial request was considered too broad and burdensome. I apologize. Please consider the modified request below:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All internal memos/callouts regarding the implementation of "task-based" work sent to eligibility supervisors and eligibility workers from DPSS "line operations" (between 1/1/2021 and 12/31/2021). For reference, I am interested in how administrators communicated the shift from case-based work to task-based work to district office staff in 2021 (when most eligibility units shifted to a task-based system). 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Josh Seim

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: MPIA Request for IAD Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I am hereby requesting access to the records listed below and held by the Baltimore Police Department:

- Copies of any and all internal affairs complaints, including internal, citizen, or other agency complaints of the following officers:

1. Raymond Hunter
2. Richard Moore
3. Robert Ross
4. Ryan O'Connor
5. Ryan Reass 
6. Sandra D Forsythe 
7. Sean Dallessandro
8. Sean Jones
9. Seth Roussey
10. Sharon Diggs
11. Shawn M Reichenberg
12. Steven Fraser
13. Thomas Jackson
14. Thomas Wolf
15. Tierra Morales
16. Trevor Hinton
17. Troy Taylor
18. Valencia Vaughn
19. Vernon Fuller

- Complete investigative files for each complaint, including but not limited to reports of recorded statements, video surveillance or body camera footage, investigative files, witness interviews, and photographs.
- The investigative findings of each complaint.
- Any correspondence from the Civilian Review Board, Police Advisory Commission or other civilian police oversight board.
- The final disposition of each case, if any.

****As with previous requests of this nature,  we will accept disciplinary history summaries for all of the officers listed for the time being.****

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request.  Alternatively, please consider waiving any fees, pursuant to § 4-206(e)(2)(ii) of the General Provisions Article, as this request is on behalf of individuals served by the Maryland Office of the Public Defender, a state government agency, which solely serves indigent citizens of Maryland.  As a result, my request for the above-listed public records is in the public interest.  I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Deborah Levi
Director of Special Litigation
Maryland Office of the Public Defender
(443) 272-1068

communications.subject: Acknowledgement Letter for MPIA 24-1808
communications.communication:
Dear Deborah Levi,

This is an acknowledgement of your request below, for public information, submitted to the Document Compliance Unit ("DCU") of the Baltimore Police Department ("BPD").  Your request is governed by the Maryland Public Information Act ("PIA"), Maryland Code, General Provisions Article ("GP"), Sections 4-101 et seq.  DCU will process your request promptly.  However, our response may take longer than ten (10) working days, the reasons for which may include the scope of your request, the type and volume of potentially responsive records, and the nature of the search, review, and preparation that is required.  In any event, DCU will respond to your request within thirty (30) days. GP § 4-203.

DCU will contact you with the availability of records and the possible costs associated with this request, as soon as the information is made available by the Custodian of Records.  Likewise, if DCU and/or the Custodian of Records need you to clarify your request, DCU will contact you promptly.
The DCU staff receive overwhelming number of requests a month and we are working diligently to respond to each and every request as quickly as possible. We appreciate your patience; response to document requests may take longer than normal.

Please refer to tracking # MPIA 24-1808  in any subsequent correspondence pertaining to this matter.  All follow up correspondence should be made in writing and submitted to the DCU's e-mail: DCU@baltimorepolice.org<mailto:DCU@baltimorepolice.org>.

DCU

BPD

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Event Records (Waltham Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Records pertaining to detentions and arrests on or immediately surrounding Brandeis University's campus at 415 South Street in Waltham, MA., between September and December in the year 2023.
This should include: incident reports, case reports, supplemental reports, body-worn camera footage (if applicable), dash-cam footage (if applicable), 911 call recordings and transcripts, radio communications or dispatch logs, emails or text messages between officers, supervisors, and other officials about the incident, internal memos, briefings, or reports regarding the event, CAD (Computer-Aided Dispatch) logs, arrest reports (if applicable), and booking records.

Note for Mass. PD (Waltham PD ignore this): Brandeis Campus PD is implicated in this request as a subsidiary of Massachusetts State Police. It is subject to public records requests. See: Chapter 22C, Section 63 of the Massachusetts General laws, which allows college and university police officers to be appointed as Special State Police Officers under the authority of the Colonel of the Massachusetts State Police.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

UT

Note for Mass. PD (Waltham PD ignore this): Brandeis Campus PD is implicated in this request as a subsidiary of Massachusetts State Police. It is subject to public records requests. See: Chapter 22C, Section 63 of the Massachusetts General laws, which allows college and university police officers to be appointed as Special State Police Officers under the authority of the Colonel of the Massachusetts State Police. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage. 

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

UT

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Police data collection (2017-2022)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. the total number of use of force incidents from 2020-2023, separated by year. Please include, as part of this a breakdown, how many use of force incidents were related to law enforcement operations 
2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by year and type of force, from 2020-2023 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2023, baton incidents in 2023, etc.)
3. the total number of civilian complaints against law enforcement that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year.  
4. the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year. 
5. the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year.  
6. the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year. 
7. the total number of officer-involved shootings from 2020-2023, both fatal and non-fatal, separated by year.
8. the total number of people who the sheriff’s department used force against, broken down by race/ethnicity
9. Complaints filed by one officer towards another officer

When available, please provide the data in separate CSV files by year.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alessandro Guzman

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: PRA on pro-Palestine Encampment Protests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Emails from UC President Michael Drake, UC Regents and UC chancellors referencing policing of pro-Palestine encampment protests from March 2024-October 2024. 
- Emails from UC President Michael Drake and UC Regents referencing his departure from the UC System from May 2024-August 2024
- Emails from UC Police Chiefs and Michael Drake referencing the 2021 Campus Policing Plan from March 2024-October 2024
- Emails from UC President Michael Drake and UC Regents referencing students arrested in pro-Palestine protests from April 2024-June 2024
- Emails from representatives of UC’s investors or representatives of any corporation to UC Regents or President Michael Drake referencing pro-Palestine protest encampments from April 2024-October 2024
- Emails between state officials and UC Regents and/or UC President Michael Drake that reference pro-Palestine encampment protests from April 2024-October 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Atmika Iyer

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Agency Roster (Fullerton Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current annual salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd
