communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Nov. 8, 2022. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #2023-ICAP-00243.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
You have reached SecureRelease Support.

The purpose of this inbox is to provide technical support for the SecureRelease FOIA Request Portal website (https://www.securerelease.us/).

SecureRelease website support staff are not involved with the processing or prioritization of requests, and this inbox is not monitored by agency personnel.

According to our records, request 2023-ICAP-00243 was not submitted through the SecureRelease Request Portal, therefore, we are unable to provide online status tracking or portal messaging capabilities for this request.

We have CC’ed the ICE FOIA inbox for visibility. To follow up further on this request, please refer to communications you received from the agency for contact instructions or reach out to the agency in the same manner that you submitted your request.

Regards,

SecureRelease™ Support Team
securereleasesupportteam@deloitte.com<mailto:securereleasesupportteam@deloitte.com>
www.securerelease.us<http://www.securerelease.us>

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
Good day,

In regards to 2023-ICAP+00243, we have queried the appropriate component of DHS for responsive records.  If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability.  We will process your request as expeditiously as possible.  Upon completion of the processing, all documents that can be released will be made available to you as soon as possible.

Thank you,
ICE FOIA

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
You are legally required to provide an estimated date on which documents will be produced.

You are legally required to make a determination on this request and inform us of it. 

You are legally required to make records promptly available. 

You have failed to comply with any of these requirements. 

If you have any intention of doing so within the next fourteen days, please inform us. 

Thank you.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2023-ICAP-00243
communications.communication:
Good afternoon, 

Your assertion that “a high number of FOIA requests have been received by the Department” is unsupported by the Department’s own FY22 Chief FOIA Officer Report. In other words, you’re saying a thing that your own data demonstrate is untrue. 

But go off, I guess. 

Thank you, 

Andrew Free

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2024-ICAP-00071, 2024-ICFO-06913
communications.communication:
12/12/2023 

Andrew Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR136588 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2024-ICAP-00071, 2024-ICFO-06913 

Dear Requester: 

The Department of Homeland Security has received your letter appealing the adverse determination of your Freedom of Information Act/Privacy Act (FOIA/PA) request by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Your appeal, postmarked or electronically transmitted on 11/22/2023, was received on 12/11/2023. 

The Government Information Law Division acknowledges your appeal request of and is assigning it number 2024-ICAP-00071 for tracking purposes.  Please reference this number in any future communications about your appeal. 

A high number of FOIA/PA requests have been received by the Department.  Accordingly, we have adopted the court-sanctioned practice of generally handling backlogged appeals on a first-in, first-out basis.   While we will make every effort to process your appeal on a timely basis, there may be some delay in resolving this matter.  Should you have any questions concerning the processing of your appeal, please contact Fernando Pineiro Jr., ICE FOIA Office/Public Liaison at (866) 633-1182 or at 500 12th St., SW Washington, DC 20536-5009. 

Sincerely, 
 
Sara Jazayeri 
Acting Chief 
Government Information Law Division 
ICE Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security

As of today, the search for responsive documents is complete and your request is currently in queue to be processed. If responsive records have been located, they will be reviewed for a determination of releasability. 

ICE FOIA apologizes for the delay in the processing of your request. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions, please contact FOIA Public Liaison, Daniel Edgington at the address above or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2024-ICAP-00162. Please use this number in future correspondence.

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2024-ICAP-00127
communications.communication:
08/12/2024 

Andrew Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR136588 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2024-ICAP-00127 

Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Appeal on remand. You had appealed an adverse determination of your request dated 1/23/2024. 

We have considered your request under the both the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the Privacy Act Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552a.  After review of the documents, I have determined that portions of documents will be withheld pursuant to Exemption 6 of the Privacy Act and Exemptions 7 of the FOIA as described below. 

FOIA Exemption 5 protects from disclosure those inter- or intra-agency documents that are normally privileged in the civil discovery context.  The three most frequently invoked privileges are the deliberative process privilege, the attorney work-product privilege, and the attorney-client privilege.  After carefully reviewing the responsive documents, I have determined that portions of the responsive documents qualify for protection under the deliberative process privilege/ attorney work-product privilege/ attorney-client privilege/ or all three.  The deliberative process privilege protects the integrity of the deliberative or decision-making processes within the agency by exempting from mandatory disclosure opinions, conclusions, and recommendations included within inter-agency or intra-agency memoranda or letters.  The release of this internal information would discourage the expression of candid opinions and inhibit the free and frank exchange of information among agency personnel. The attorney work-product privilege protects documents and other memoranda prepared by an attorney in contemplation of litigation. 

FOIA Exemption 6 exempts from disclosure personnel or medical files and similar files the release of which would cause a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This requires a balancing of the public’s right to disclosure against the individual’s right privacy.  The types of documents and/or information that we have withheld may consist of social security numbers, home addresses, dates of birth, or various other documents and/or information belonging to a third party that are considered personal.  The privacy interests of the individuals in the records you have requested outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into the aforementioned balancing test. 

FOIA Exemption 7(C) protects records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes that could reasonably be expected to constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This exemption takes particular note of the strong interests of individuals, whether they are suspects, witnesses, or investigators, in not being unwarrantably associated with alleged criminal activity.  That interest extends to persons who are not only the subjects of the investigation, but those who may have their privacy invaded by having their identities and information about them revealed in connection with an investigation.  Based upon the traditional recognition of strong privacy interest in law enforcement records, categorical withholding of information that identifies third parties in law enforcement records is ordinarily appropriate.  As such, I have determined that the privacy interest in the identities of individuals in the records you have requested clearly outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Please note that any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into this determination. 

Exemption 7(E) protects records compiled for law enforcement purposes, the release of which would disclose techniques and/or procedures for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions, or would disclose guidelines for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions if such disclosure could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law.  I determined that disclosure of law enforcement systems checks could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law.  Additionally, the techniques and procedures at issue are not well known to the public. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009. 

Sincerely, 

Supervisory Paralegal Specialist

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: NJ Drones
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records related to aerial sightings reported in New Jersey during November and December 2024. These sightings, widely described as “mystery drones” or Unidentified Aerial Phenomena (UAP), have been the subject of significant public interest and media coverage.

This request specifically seeks access to all records created, received, or modified between November 1, 2024, and the date of this request's fulfillment. To ensure the identification of all responsive materials, this request includes references to "mystery drones," "UAP," "unidentified flying objects (UFOs)," "unmanned aerial systems (UAS)," "unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs)," "aerial anomalies," or any similar terminology used to describe these aerial sightings.

The requested records include, but are not limited to:

Audio and Video Files: All audio or video files received, recorded, or obtained by the department related to these sightings. This includes recordings made by departmental surveillance equipment, body-worn cameras, dashboard cameras, or agency-operated drones, as well as media submitted by citizens, contractors, or third parties. I request the original or highest-resolution versions of these files and associated metadata, including timestamps, geolocation data, technical specifications of recording devices, and any embedded identifiers for classification, dissemination tracking, or chain of custody.

Associated Analyses and Documentation: All investigative reports, intelligence summaries, or briefings prepared in connection with these sightings. This includes assessments of their origin, behavior, or potential significance, such as whether they posed a security, safety, or privacy threat. I also request documentation of decisions or deliberations regarding the classification, distribution, or public disclosure of information related to these events.

Communications and Directives: All internal and inter-agency communications referencing these aerial phenomena, including any correspondence that references "mystery drones," UAP, or similar terms. This includes records of communications with external entities, such as contractors, private organizations, foreign governments or international bodies, and federal, state, or local agencies involved in investigating or responding to these incidents.

Records of Federal Collaboration: All records documenting referrals, consultations, or information sharing with federal agencies such as the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), Department of Defense (DoD), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), or any other relevant entities.

If the scope of this request is deemed overly broad, I am willing to work with your office to refine it to ensure the timely identification and release of responsive records. I also request that responsive records be provided in their original electronic format, preserving all metadata.

If any portions of the requested records are exempt under public records laws, I request that non-exempt portions be released. For any classified materials, I request a mandatory declassification review under applicable laws, including Executive Order 13526.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Bill Gagnon

communications.subject: Notice of Special Service Charge to Gagnon, Bill  Date: January 2, 2025
communications.communication:
Mr. Bill Gagnon,

You have filed an OPRA request for audio recordings related to the reporting of mystery drones, UAVs, UAPs, UAS, UFOs and "aerial anomalies. Calls placed to this Agency between November 1, 2024 and December 28, 2024 number about 100 calls. Due to the number of calls and the time required to review and redact "Personal Identifying Information (PII)" from these calls Special Service Charge will be applied. Please see the attached documents which explain the Special Service Charge.

If you wish to continue with this request then you must respond in writing within 7 days of this email. Failure to do so, will render this request closed. Payment must be made via check to the COUNTY OF OCEAN C/O Michael Zolezi Ocean County Sheriff's Office, Records Custodian. The check must clear before this agency begins to process your OPRA request. Any questions or concerns please contact me at MZolezi@co.ocean.nj.us<mailto:MZolezi@co.ocean.nj.us>.

Best Regards,

Michael Zolezi
Records Custodian
Ocean County Sheriff's Office

MZolezi@co.ocean.nj.us<mailto:MZolezi@co.ocean.nj.us>
732-929-2044 Ext. 3062

Notice of Special Service Charge to Gagnon, Bill  Date: January 2, 2025

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Georgia Public Broadcasting Strategic Plan
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of any completed or draft strategic plan for Georgia Public Broadcasting as commissioned by GPB from the Carl Vinson Institute or other outside consultant between July 1, 2023 and Dec. 31, 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brian Patrick Bannon

communications.subject: RE: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Georgia Public Broadcasting Strategic Plan

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Agency Roster (Reno Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

  * Investigative Technique ((Confidential Law Enforcement Technique / Donrey of Nevada v. Bradshaw 106 Nev. 630,. 798 P.2d 144 (1990)) 
  * The names of RPD undercover officers are not included in this list.  These officers have a nontrivial personal privacy interest in having their identity protected; they did not surrender their privacy interests by swearing an oath of public office. The release of their names could subject them to harassment, retaliation and/or personal safety threats which the Nevada Supreme Court recognizes as cognizable privacy interests. Finally, the release of the officers’ names is unlikely to advance a significant public interest.  Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department v. Las Vegas Review Journal, 136 Nev 733, 478 P.3d 383 (2020); See also Clark County School District  v. Las Vegas Review-Journal, 134 Nev. 700, 429 P.3d 313 (2018). 
Your request has been satisfied. If there are other public records you wish to review that are not covered by the City’s response, please submit your request. communications.subject: Welcome to the Records Request Center!
communications.communication:
Dear Robbie Powelson, 
 
Thank you for registering with the Public Records Request Center.

title: South Carolina ORR Noncitizen Voting 07.12.24 (Secretary Of State South Carolina)

communications.subject: South Carolina Public Records Law Request: South Carolina ORR Noncitizen Voting 07.12.24 (Secretary Of State South Carolina)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the South Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Documented requests all electronic records containing the following keywords and email domains: 

Keywords and phrases: 
“Non citizen voting”
“Only Citizens vote”
“Illegals voting”
“Election Integrity Network” 
“EIN” 
“Jenny Beth Martin”  
“Kerri Toloczko”
“Lindsey Zea”
“Melody Clarke”
“Cleta Mitchell” 
“Kyle Brosnan” 
“Rosemary Jenks” 
“Immigration Accountability Project”
“America First Legal” 
“America First Policy Institute” 
“Election Transparency Initiative” 
“Ken Blackwell” 
“Hogan Gidley” 
“Ken Cuccinneli” 
“Oversight Project” 
“Heritage Foundation” 
“J. Christian Adams”
“Andy Roth”
“Evan Newman”
“Eagle AI”
“Eagle Eye”


Email domains: 
“@virginiainstitute.org”
“@unite4freedom.com” 
“@electionintegrity.network”
“@teapartypatriots.org” 
“@iaproject.org”
“@AFL.org” 
“@americafirstpolicy.com” 

The scope of this request includes the following legislators and all staff that report directly to the legislators: 

Secretary of State Mark Hammond
Governor Henry McMaster

The search for records should include sent and received emails and any other electronic records including, but not limited to, scheduling and calendar records, text messages, and messages on messaging platforms, such as Slack, GChat or Google Hangouts, iMessage, WhatsApp, Signal, Telegram, Skype, Twitter direct messages, Facebook Messenger, or Parler. The search for email records should also include any email accounts used to conduct official business, including personal email addresses such as a "gmail" or "yahoo" account.

Please include any attachments to those records and other materials enclosed with those records at the time they were transmitted. For instance, for an email that is responsive to our request, please include all prior messages sent or received in that email chain, as well as any attachments to the email.

The search for records may be limited to records created, sent or received between January 1st, 2024 through to the date of your final response.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, please notify me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be filled electronically by email attachment if available, or CD-ROM if not.

Please confirm receipt of this request. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response.
Sincerely,
Victoria Cadostin 
857-504-4870

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Victoria Cadostin

Dear Ms. Cadostin,

Thank you for reaching out to the South Carolina Secretary of State's Office.  On July 29, 2024, our office received your Freedom of Information Act request.  At this time, we anticipate that the fee for the staff time for the search, retrieval, and redaction (if needed) of the records you have requested will be $131.09.  Pursuant to S.C. Code Section 30-4-30(B), our office will require a 25% deposit of this amount prior to searching for the records you have requested.  If you would like to proceed with your request, please remit a check or money order in the amount of $32.77 to my attention at the following address:  SC Secretary of State's Office, 1205 Pendleton Street, Suite 525, Columbia, SC 29201.  Once the search, retrieval, and redaction of the records are complete, I will notify you of the final cost for producing the records.  

Also, please note that in South Carolina, the Secretary of State's Office does not conduct elections or register voters.  That duty falls under the South Carolina State Election Commission (please see the State Election Commission's website at https://scvotes.gov/).  Our office does convene the meeting of the Electoral College every four years.  Since your request appears to be elections related, I wanted to make sure you were aware of the scope of our agency's statutory responsibility with respect to this area.  

If you have any questions, or would like to discuss this matter further, please let me know.  You may contact me directly at swiley@sos.sc.gov or (803) 734-0246.

Sincerely,
Shannon A. Wiley
General Counsel & Public Information Director
South Carolina Secretary of State’s Office

communications.subject: RE: South Carolina Public Records Law Request: South Carolina ORR Noncitizen Voting 07.12.24 (Secretary Of State South Carolina)
communications.communication:
Hi Shannon, 

Thank you for getting back to me with this information. Would you be able to provide a breakdown of how the cost estimate is calculated? Thanks again, I look forward to hearing from you. 


My best, 
Victoria

Thank you and have a great day!

Shannon

communications.subject: RE: RE: South Carolina Public Records Law Request: South Carolina ORR Noncitizen Voting 07.12.24 (Secretary Of State South Carolina)
communications.communication:
Hi Victoria,

Thank you for your patience on this matter.  Our IT Division has completed the search and retrieval of the records you requested.  There are 33 records that contain the keywords provided in your request that were sent to or from Secretary of State Mark Hammond and/or Deputy Secretary of State & Chief Legal Counsel Melissa Dunlap.  Please note that we did not include records that contain the abbreviation "EIN" for which the abbreviation referred to the term "Employer Identification Number" instead of "Election Integrity Network."  However, if you would like these records included, please let me know.  Also, please note that we do not have any relevant records that were sent to or form Governor Henry McMaster or his direct reports.  For these records, you may want to contact his office directly.

The total fee for the search and retrieval of the records was $97.32.  Since you remitted a deposit in the amount of $32.77, the remaining balance is $64.55.  Please see the attached invoice reflecting this balance.  Upon receipt of the balance, I will email the records to you.  If you have any questions or need anything further in the interim, please let me know.

Thank you again and have a great weekend.

Shannon

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: "Mosquito Device"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Contracts, NDAs, manuals, and other memorandum related to the acquisition and installation of the "Mosquito Device" noise machine at Crossroads park
2. Communications including but not limited to emails, text messages, Microsoft Teams messages, etc regarding the acquisition and installation of the device. For responsive text messages and Teams messages, please provide messages sent in the same chat within 30 minutes for context.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: C000696-082024
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
Thank you for your interest in obtaining public records held by City of Bellevue.  Your request was received on 8/20/2024 12:32:17 PM and given the reference number C000696-082024 for tracking purposes. 
Within five (5) business days after receiving your request, we will provide one of the responses below. The day the request is received does not count as one of the five (5) days. Weekends and holidays observed by the City are also excluded in the calculation. 
 
  *  acknowledge receipt of the request and give a reasonable estimate of the time needed; 
  *  provide an internet address or link to the requested records; 
  *  produce the requested records; or, deny all or part of the request in writing. Record(s) Requested: 1.	Contracts, NDAs, manuals, and other memorandum related to the acquisition and installation of the "Mosquito Device" noise machine at Crossroads park

2.	Communications including but not limited to emails, text messages, Microsoft Teams messages, etc regarding the acquisition and installation of the device. For responsive text messages and Teams messages, please provide messages sent in the same chat within 30 minutes for context. 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant City department(s) to locate the records and to determine the volume and any costs associated with satisfying your request.  You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Sincerely, Bellevue Public Records City Clerk's Office

Subject: City of Bellevue Public Records Request C000696-082024 
August 22, 2024 Dear Rose Terse, 

This email is to confirm that the City of Bellevue has received a public records request from you pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, Ch. 42.56 RCW. Your new public disclosure request number is C000696-082024, which will help us locate your information if you contact us for an update. We are working on your request and estimate that a response will be available on or about September 27, 2024. 

You are requesting: 

1. Contracts, NDAs, manuals, and other memorandum related to the acquisition and installation of the "Mosquito Device" noise machine at Crossroads park 

2. Communications including but not limited to emails, text messages, Microsoft Teams messages, etc regarding the acquisition and installation of the device. For responsive text messages and Teams messages, please provide messages sent in the same chat within 30 minutes for context. 
We will start the process of identifying records. If additional clarification is needed or there is any change to our response timeline, we will be sure to let you know. Please let us know if you have any questions regarding the processing of your request. 

Sincerely, 
Haley Havens 
Bellevue Public Records 
425-452-4283

communications.communication:

Subject: Clarification Requested for Public Records Request C000696-082024 
August 23, 2024 Dear Rose Terse, 

We have received your request for: 1. Contracts, NDAs, manuals, and other memorandum related to the acquisition and installation of the "Mosquito Device" noise machine at Crossroads park2. Communications including but not limited to emails, text messages, Microsoft Teams messages, etc regarding the acquisition and installation of the device. For responsive text messages and Teams messages, please provide messages sent in the same chat within 30 minutes for context. 
In order to respond to your request, we need clarification on your request as follows: 1. Could you provide a date range for your request? 2. When you say "...acquisition and installation...", do you mean operational emails only (internal), or do you also want us to include emails from the public? I performed a global email search using the following terms [Mosquito device, mosquito noise, sonic device, sonic devices, sonic deterrent, crossroads restroom, crossroads white paper, and mosquito] and the search returned about 7000 emails. Depending how "acquisition and installation" is interpreted will affect how much email is turned over to you. 
Once we receive your response we will be able to provide an estimated date of release. 

Sincerely, 
Haley Havens Bellevue Public Records 
425-452-4283

Thank you,
Rose

communications.communication:

Subject: 1st Installment: Public Records Request C000696-082024 September 27, 2024 Dear Rose Terse, We have made an installment to your Public Records Request C000696-082024 available for your inspection.  You may access the responsive records provided in the Public Records Portal.  Parks provided this information with the record: The purchase was made using the City of Bellevue’s Foreign Purchases Pro Card as it was purchase from a Canadian company. The approval and paid invoice are uploaded as the responsive record. Per the State Public Records Act (RCW 42.56.120) and City Public Records Act Rules (Section 6), a public records request may be considered abandoned and subsequently closed if a requester fails to fulfill their obligation to claim an installment of records; claim the entire production of records; inspect the records; or fails to pay the deposit or final payment for requested records within 30 days of this notification. Pursuant to the Public Records Act RCW 42.56, responsive records may be redacted or exempt. Please review the accompanying privilege log for further information, if such redactions or exemptions have been applied. Pursuant to Section 11 of the City's Public Records Act Rules, any person who objects to the initial denial or partial denial of a records request may petition in writing (including by email) to the Public Records Officer for review of that decision. The petition shall include a copy of, or reasonably identify, the written statement by the Public Records Officer or designee denying the request and the basis for the challenge to the denial. Please mail or email your appeal to: Public Records Officer Bellevue City Hall - City Clerk's Office 450 110th Ave NE Bellevue WA 98004 Email: publicrecords@bellevuewa.gov (mailto:publicrecords@bellevuewa.gov) We estimate an update or installment will be provided on or about October 25, 2024. Please let us know if you have any questions or concerns regarding the processing of this request. Sincerely, Haley Havens Bellevue Public Records 425-452-4283

Appreciate your help with this request so far! Sorry for the delay but I was able to narrow down my search criteria based on the search result spreadsheets you sent over.

Please limit the search to communications between City accounts with the addition of email addresses ending in @movingsoundtech.com from 7/1/2024 through the date this request was received (8/7/2024) which contain the exact terms "mosquito" and/or "sonic device". Additionally, please exclude any "Latest Bellevue News & Media Clips" emails from your search.

Please let me know if that narrows down the set of responsive records we're looking at.

Thank you,
Rose

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line. Anything below will not be viewable to staff. --- 
Subject: Abandoned/Closed: Public Records Request C000696-082024 
November 12, 2024 Dear Rose Terse, 
On October 11, 2024, we notified you that responsive records are available for inspection in the public records portal. The installment fulfilled the modified request, and without further communication from you, there is nothing more to provide. 
Per the State Public Records Act (RCW 42.56.120) and City Public Records Act Rules (Section 6), a public records request may be considered abandoned and subsequently closed if a requestor fails to fulfill their obligation to claim an installment of records; claim the entire production of records; inspect the records; or fails to pay the deposit or final payment for requested records within 30 days of this notification. 
This is our final, definitive response and this request is now considered abandoned and closed as of the date of this communication. As the city does not intend to further address the request, the Public Records Act one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review has now started to run. Records previously released in this request will remain available for you to view and download from the Public Records Portal. Please contact us in the next 30 days if you have any follow-up questions or concerns regarding the processing of this request. Sincerely, Haley Havens Bellevue Public Records 425-452-4283

From the records I have reviewed, it looks like these are only emails between the City and Moving Sound Tech.

Again, so sorry for the confusion! Would you please provide these records as well?

Thank you,
Rose

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line. Anything below will not be viewable to staff. --- 
Subject: 3rd Installment: Public Records Request C000696-082024 December 06, 2024 Dear Rose Terse, We have made an installment to your Public Records Request C000696-082024 available for your inspection.  You may access the responsive records provided in the Public Records Portal.  Per the State Public Records Act (RCW 42.56.120) and City Public Records Act Rules (Section 6), a public records request may be considered abandoned and subsequently closed if a requester fails to fulfill their obligation to claim an installment of records; claim the entire production of records; inspect the records; or fails to pay the deposit or final payment for requested records within 30 days of this notification. Pursuant to the Public Records Act RCW 42.56, responsive records may be redacted or exempt. Please review the accompanying privilege log for further information, if such redactions or exemptions have been applied. Pursuant to Section 11 of the City's Public Records Act Rules, any person who objects to the initial denial or partial denial of a records request may petition in writing (including by email) to the Public Records Officer for review of that decision. The petition shall include a copy of, or reasonably identify, the written statement by the Public Records Officer or designee denying the request and the basis for the challenge to the denial. Please mail or email your appeal to: Public Records Officer Bellevue City Hall - City Clerk's Office 450 110th Ave NE Bellevue WA 98004 Email: publicrecords@bellevuewa.gov (mailto:publicrecords@bellevuewa.gov) We estimate an update or installment will be provided on or about January 3, 2025. Please let us know if you have any questions or concerns regarding the processing of this request. Sincerely, Haley Havens Bellevue Public Records 425-452-4283

Subject: 4th Installment and Close: Public Records Request C000696-082024 December 31, 2024 Dear Rose Terse, We are releasing records in response to your request: 1. Contracts, NDAs, manuals, and other memorandum related to the acquisition and installation of the "Mosquito Device" noise machine at Crossroads park 

2. Communications including but not limited to emails, text messages, Microsoft Teams messages, etc regarding the acquisition and installation of the device. For responsive text messages and Teams messages, please provide messages sent in the same chat within 30 minutes for context. I am releasing communications between City accounts with the addition of email addresses ending in @movingsoundtech.com from 7/1/2024 through the date this request was received (8/7/2024) which contain the exact terms "mosquito", "sonic device", "sonic devices", "sonic deterrent". You may access records in the Public Records Portal. (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXbUWSWnJYM-2FRewwjUGmaQvk3yoWDPX1GwXa7YPhBTXaPTca2sURm2Xvj7i4fw-2BQ9-2BIOkHNps-2F2jV2UgUe1G21w9gVh1JM3GNwocBmpO62bHG5LLJ_mQMCqzjqmyfaR1CipFqH-2FaExp9Ws-2FSD3uwo7XNOkn-2FSMkh4HwjEQ0XtHjG0s8QQKEA1shjrROMu2Qtszj8GRgalFjSO-2B-2BmQQMusmpKuxOenOac-2FsvdFo8tKiyCXzL20ADe1LfxHOFnfKgNQ4mTpqFwD9v-2BpzYj-2F3HkIVxBQqfSTnhifxLa8epxfkrbmGcBAfysLldPtvsioUUzH-2B1YeM4nkBF1SzNZNQb5knBr-2BOvJ6oCt7zjDuSGnI6c7vZfEAOegJ7WrujrqKrd2Z35-2BlNIohzbNyuLqLoSqquauVonDAeCAbi6L2zu3Tz3WyZMfNWu2eENHoAIQLwI-2BKBemnaAld7S3Av0Kt9epeqzbesvfw0wapPo7G5UqVPLug-2BKaZG) 
This is our final, definitive response and your request is closed.  As the city does not intend to further address the request, the Public Records Act one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review has now started to run. communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Roy Den Hollander
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1.) Any and all records mentioning, referencing, or concerning Roy Den Hollander (September 26, 1947 - July 20, 2020). 

Roy Den Hollander was an American lawyer who gained notoriety as a suspected murderer after acting as an attorney in several unsuccessful sex discrimination suits on behalf of men. He was, allegedly, also a private investigator in Russia (Kroll Associates Russia).

Den Hollander, who had earlier stated he was "dying from cancer", was found dead on July 20, 2020, outside a rental car from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, which contributed to him being made a suspect in the July 2020 murder of lawyer Marc Angelucci in California and, eight days later, an attack on the family of U.S. District Judge Esther Salas in New Jersey, in which Salas's son Daniel Anderl was killed and Salas's husband, Mark Anderl, was seriously wounded.

Proof of death in links below:

https://www.cbsnews.com/news/roy-den-hollander-murder-suicide-48-hours/

https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/213865536/roy-den_hollander

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joanne Riford

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to

requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1550703-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 98 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 947 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,011 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,360 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Sonny Carter NASA Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The NASA personnel file and service record for Manley Lanier "Sonny" Carter, Jr., M.D., who died in a plane crash in April 1994: https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/167748main_fs_nbl508c.pdf?emrc=67e772.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

title: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)
communications.communication:
MuckRock News
DEPT MR 146407
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115

Dutchess County District Attorney
Attn: FOIA Officer


Subject: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)

Dear FOIA Officer,

Under the provisions of the Dutchess County Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) or any applicable state laws, I hereby request access to and copies of all records held by the Dutchess County District Attorney's Office pertaining to Albert Fentress.

I am an independent investigative journalist associated with TransparencyReport.pw, and I am conducting research on the history and activities of Albert Fentress. Albert Fentress is a convicted criminal who gained notoriety for his involvement in the abduction, rape, and murder of a college student in Poughkeepsie in the late 1980s. Fentress was arrested, tried, and convicted for these heinous crimes, and his case has been a subject of public interest and scrutiny for several years.

Additionally, there have been further allegations against Albert Fentress, including suspicions of involvement in other unsolved cases of a similar nature. These allegations have raised concerns within the community and have sparked discussions about the extent of Fentress's criminal activities. Therefore, I believe it is crucial to access the requested records to shed light on these allegations and provide a comprehensive understanding of the investigations conducted by the Dutchess County District Attorney's Office.

For the purpose of this request, the records I seek include, but are not limited to:

Arrest records and charging documents related to Albert Fentress.
Court records, including judgments, verdicts, and sentencing information.
Investigative documents, such as police reports, incident reports, and any other documents related to Albert Fentress.
Correspondence and communications, including emails, letters, memoranda, or any other written exchanges mentioning or involving Albert Fentress.
Any audio or visual recordings, such as interviews, interrogations, or surveillance footage related to Albert Fentress.
Any internal memos, policies, or guidelines concerning the handling of Albert Fentress's case.
Given the profound impact of Albert Fentress's crimes on the community and the ongoing interest in understanding the scope of his criminal activities, accessing these records will contribute significantly to the public's understanding of the operations and activities of the Dutchess County District Attorney's Office.

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with the applicable laws. If an entire document is exempt, I request a justification, citing specific exemptions under the relevant laws.

Please note your obligation under the law not to destroy any records potentially responsive to this request. Any withholding, redaction, or destruction of responsive records without proper justification constitutes a violation of the FOIA and is subject to litigation.

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with TransparencyReport.pw, I firmly believe that the information I seek is in the public interest, and its disclosure will greatly contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government.

If the enclosed waiver is not accepted and there are any potential charges associated with fulfilling my request, please inform me in advance.

As stipulated by the FOIA or applicable state laws, I look forward to your response within the legally mandated timeframe.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.


Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
TransparencyReport.pw
Email: Jordan@Lassiter.eu
Phone: +1 845-218-0299

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter

Please be aware: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing communications, will be treated in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations. Additionally, any correspondence in relation to this request may be subject to public disclosure, as required by law. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: Re: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Lassiter,

We have received your request and I've located the files on Albert Fentress. Due to the length and nature of his confinement, I am sifting through voluminous files—many of which I am finding are not relevant to your request.

I do believe we possess many of the documents you are looking for, though. I will provide you a detailed list of what we have available to turn over no later than October 13, 2023.

When the time comes, I can upload the documents to our discovery portal and send you an encrypted link and password if that is acceptable to you. Most prefer this method since it avoids any fees. Please feel free to reach out with any questions.

Kind regards,

Amie

Amie M. Johnson
Senior Assistant District Attorney
Dutchess County District Attorney's Office
236 Main Street, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
Office: (845) 486-2300| Fax: (845) 486-6506
ajohnson@dutchessny.gov

communications.subject: Re: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Thanks for following up on this. I am still in the process of inventorying the boxes of files on Fentress. Since this was an atypical murder case in which he is not jailed--but rather is being held under Criminal Procedure Law 330.20--his case comes back up every 2 years for review. This, in conjunction with the fact that he has been held for over 40 years, means that we have generated (and will continue to generate) an enormous amount of correspondence/communications on his case. My conservative estimate based on what I've seen so far would be 1000+ pages of communications.

I don't think I'll have any issue finding the other items you're requesting, but please let me know if there are specific communications you are seeking to help narrow the search. I will give you another update next week. I at least hope to have a list of all of the documents we have by 10/20/23 and then we can figure out which ones you'd like.

Have a good weekend,

Amie

Amie M. Johnson
Senior Assistant District Attorney
Dutchess County District Attorney's Office
236 Main Street, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
Office: (845) 486-2300| Fax: (845) 486-6506
ajohnson@dutchessny.gov

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)
communications.communication:
Subject: Follow-up on FOIA Request - Case of Fentress

Dear Ms. Johnson,

I hope this email finds you well. Thank you for your prompt response and the information you provided regarding the status of my FOIA request for documents related to the case of Fentress.

I appreciate your dedication to reviewing the extensive communications and files associated with this atypical murder case. It's understandable that a case spanning over 40 years, coupled with the recurring reviews under Criminal Procedure Law 330.20, would result in a substantial volume of documentation.

I understand the challenges involved in navigating through such a vast amount of information. Your commitment to providing a comprehensive list of documents by 10/20/23 is duly noted, and I eagerly anticipate the update.

Thank you for your continued efforts, and I look forward to hearing from you next week.

Best regards,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)
communications.communication:
Subject: Urgent Compliance Required for Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Request by 02/30/2024

Dear FOIA Officer,

I am writing to express my serious concerns regarding the non-compliance with my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated July 19, 2023, related to records on Albert Fentress. The delay in providing the requested information appears to be in violation of the FOIA guidelines.

As mandated by the Freedom of Information Act, agencies are generally required to respond to a FOIA request within 20 working days of receipt, as per 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A). The ongoing delay in fulfilling this request is inconsistent with these statutory requirements.

Drawing upon legal precedents like "NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co.," 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which emphasize the importance of adhering to FOIA deadlines, I urge your office to provide the requested information promptly.

To avoid potential legal action, where a court might compel compliance and possibly award legal costs and attorney’s fees as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(E), I request that the documents be provided no later than February 30, 2024.

I hope this matter can be resolved amicably and swiftly, and I look forward to your prompt response and the release of the requested records.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
TransparencyReport.pw
Email: Jordan@Lassiter.eu

communications.subject: Re: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Investigative Journalism Request - Unveiling the Truth: Records on Albert Fentress (FOIA)
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

We are still working on getting responsive documents to you regarding the Albert Fentress case. I am currently out of the office, but I will have an update for you by the end of next week.

title: Chief FOIA officer's recent email (Defense Intelligence Agency)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Chief FOIA officer's recent email (Defense Intelligence Agency)
communications.communication:
Dear Defense Intelligence Agency,

On behalf of myself and Fiat Fiendum, I hereby request the following records:

1. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's email inbox or equivalent which was received nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter.
2. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's email spam folder or equivalent which was received nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter.
3. The one email in your chief FOIA officer's sent email folder or equivalent which was sent nearest and before October 19, 2024, midnight Eastern time, regardless of subject matter.
4. The total full-time equivalent count of people who work for your FOIA office as of October 19, 2024.

This request is expressly limited to Defense Intelligence Agency's own FOIA office. Please do not refer it to any other agency or division. This request is expressly not a Privacy Act request, and no PA waiver will be provided.

Please provide the email records in EML, Maildir, MBOX, MIX, MSG, or PST format only — not PDF, Word, image, etc — including all metadata (e.g. full email headers as received/sent) and attachments, without alteration other than narrowly tailored electronic redaction of specifically claimed exemptions that do not affect any part of non exempt information (and, in particular, without rasterization).

Please provide the fourth record as a statement in your response letter, or at your option, as the most readily available record, in original electronic format as currently stored on your computer systems, which includes that information.

Please provide all records either as individual files, or as an unencrypted ZIP file, uploaded to MuckRock. Do not apply any encryption, DRM, or other restriction.

I request fee waiver, because
* Fiat Fiendum is a 501(c)(3) non-profit;
* this request is for public interest, non-commercial purposes;
* these records would give a snapshot of insight into the everyday processes of FOIA offices; and
* these records are being requested in order to conduct a government-wide audit of agencies' FOIA compliance.

In the event that you deny fee waiver, please process this request as-is, because I will not agree to any fees.

Please be sure to provide:
* 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(II) FOIA Public Liaison information
* 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(III)(aa) appeal information
* 5 USC 552(a)(6)(A)(i)(III)(bb) OGIS information
* 5 USC 552(a)(7)(A) tracking number
* 5 USC 552(a)(7)(B)(ii) completion ETA

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,
Sai
President, Fiat Fiendum, Inc.

P.S. Sai is my full legal name.

The review status for FOIA requests are as follows:

  1.  Initial Processing
  2.  Records Search/Review
  3.  Record Processing
  4.  Quality Control Review
  5.  Additional Action Required
  6.  Delivery to the Requester

Your request FOIA-00024-2025 is currently in stage 1


Important Notes:

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Bernie Marcus
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into billionaire Home Depot founder and political donor Bernard Marcus (May 12, 1929 – Oct. 20, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Post obituary at the following link: https://nypost.com/2024/11/05/business/billionaire-home-depot-co-founder-bernie-marcus-dead-at-95/

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an assistant editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest for the Daily Beast, the Asia Times, Responsible Statecraft, the National Interest, Reason Magazine, America Magazine and the Armenian Weekly, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Northern Essex CC Vendor Expenses, FY15-FY24

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Northern Essex CC Vendor Expenses, FY15-FY24
communications.communication:
Hello,

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I am hereby submitting a Public Records Request for all money given from Northern Essex Community College to external vendors/suppliers in FY2015 through (and including) FY2024, a total of 10 years.

Specifically, the data I am requesting include (but are not limited to):
* all vendors, suppliers, individuals, and public-private partnerships
* all materials, goods, services, properties, commodities, equipment leases, property leases, and licenses
* all catalog orders, non-catalog orders, blanket orders, direct payments, bank card purchases, strategic sourcing, and competitive procurements
* all auxiliary services purchases (starts in 2022, may be from a different accounting system)
* all purchase orders, requisitions, and invoices
* all products, goods, services, contracts, and subcontracts
* all accounts, classes, commodities, and departments
* regardless of the funding source

I’m requesting the data in a single Excel spreadsheet file (.xlsx format) with at least the following columns:
* Amount
* Supplier/Vendor Name
* Account Description
* Commodity Description
* Fiscal Year
* Department/Origin Description

Please report every expense, even if one or more of the above fields is blank. Please also include negative expense amounts, which is rare but does occur.

In case it’s helpful, I've attached an image example of what I’m hoping to receive. The columns may be in any order, and the fiscal years may be on one sheet or different sheets. The columns can be sorted in any order, or unsorted if that’s easiest.

I’m anticipating that this request may be fulfilled by a simple financial report generation and export of the generated file, and therefore shouldn’t take much human time or incur any fees. Please let me know immediately if this isn’t the case, so I can modify my request as necessary to meet the PRL deadline of 10 business days.

Please email the Excel file by the deadline of Monday August 26th, 2024.

Thank you very much!

Sincerely,

AJ Vincelli
Graduate Student Union at UMass Dartmouth

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Northern Essex CC Vendor Expenses, FY15-FY24
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon AJ Vincelli,

We write to you to request a 20-day extension for response to this request because of the difficulty of the request pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 66, Section 10(C)(i)-(vi) and 950 CMR 32.06(4)(e). Northern Essex Community College is currently engaged in start of the fall semester, as well as other start-of-semester activities. As such, this is an incredibly busy time for the College involving key college employees including many of whom will be asked to assist in responding to this request.

Thank you in advance for your consideration and please do not hesitate to let me know if you have any questions or require further information to support this extension request.

Kathleen Teixeira
Northern Essex Community College
Senior Executive Assistant to CFO/COO
Administration and Finance
100 Elliott Street
Haverhill, MA 01830
(978) 556-3892

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Northern Essex CC Vendor Expenses, FY15-FY24
communications.communication:
Hi Kathleen,

Thank you for this info, and I apologize for my delay in replying.

I think this looks good! Am I correct that if there is no number in the  last column (Amount), or if the number is 0, then it is not an expense and that row can be ignored?

Thanks again,

AJ Vincelli

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Northern Essex CC Vendor Expenses, FY15-FY24
communications.communication:
Hi Kathleen,

I'm just checking on my earlier question.

Am I correct that if there is no number in the last column (Amount), or if the number is 0, then it is not an expense and that row can be ignored?

Thanks,

AJ Vincelli

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Northern Essex CC Vendor Expenses, FY15-FY24
communications.communication:
AJ Vincelli,

Yes, to confirm, blank or "0" indicates no expense.

Happy Holidays,

Kathleen Teixeira
